question: So, there you are... I've been upstairs looking all over for you...
answer: Oh, I thought you were already on the high seas.

question: No, not yet, Dad.
answer: Isn't it fashionable any more to put on a sailor's cap with the name of the yacht?

question: No, Dad, it isn't.
answer: And how long will you be away?

question: Four or five days.
answer: Oh, very well. I'll just spend the weekend alone by myself and take a little rest. I should be used to it by now.

question: Used to what?
answer: To the fact of my retirement, not only as a diplomat but also as a father.

question: But how could you say such a thing?
answer: Because it's true. After thirty years -- not having ever spoken the truth to anyone, I should at least allow myself to do so with my own daughter.

question: And have you any other truths to tell me?
answer: You already know what they are.

question: You mean Sandro, don't you? Well, I beg of you, please, spare me that. Goodbye, Dad.
answer: That type will never marry you, my child.

question: Up until now, Dad, I've been the one who hasn't wanted to marry him.
answer: It's the same thing. Goodbye, dear.

question: Have you been waiting long? You'll have to excuse me.
answer: Please hurry, Alvaro. We're late.

question: I'll wait for you here. But where are you going?
answer: I'm thirsty.

question: If I had a man waiting for me for half an hour and whom I hadn't seen for a month ...
answer: You know, I could just as well go without seeing him today.

question: What! After giving us such a run around... I see... so it's farewell to the yacht...and farewell to the cruise...
answer: You know, it's terrible to be far away from one another. Really, it's difficult to keep an affair going when one is here and the other is somewhere else. But, at the same time...it's comforting. Because it gives you a chance to consider what you want and how you want it... but when he's right there before you all the time... well, he's right there... Oh, let's go back....

question: I have a feeling that you're not used to being alone.
answer: That seems to apply to you also...

question: Don't be so humble.
answer: How should I be ... arrogant?

question: But of course... arrogant, haughty... Hasn't Anna ever told you?
answer: It was lovelier before.

question: Like this?
answer: It's all my fault!

question: You must know your third grade geography book inside out.
answer: What is that one over there called?

question: That must be Basiluzzo.
answer: Sounds like the name of a fish -- merluzzo, basiluzzo...

question: When do you have to go back?
answer: I don't know... It depends on Ettore... He's now in the process of negotiating for a contract here in Sicily...

question: Then how come you're not with him?
answer: What a question... Because I want to be with you, naturally. I hope he doesn't close the deal so he'll leave me alone at least for a few days... Isn't this water wonderful!

question: I'd like to find a place where I can get some peace and rest, maybe around here somewhere. I'd like to try...
answer: What could be more restful than this?... Excuse me, what is it that you want to try?

question: Oh no; quite the contrary. He's really just a child.
answer: Patrizia, don't start in again... I would rather be called depraved. Unless you happen to love children.

question: You know, I don't love anybody.
answer: I know, dammit, I know! And just think -- if there ever was a woman so right, so perfectly cut out for all kinds of dissipations, degradations, infidelities... of.. . of... of debaucheries, it's her. Well, anyway, she's faithful. Faithful out of laziness... of unwillingness.

question: To the shark.
answer: Say, Claudia, wouldn't you like to climb up with me and take a look over there?

question: At what?
answer: At the ruins. They're very ancient, you know.

question: Could be. They're the kind of people who are capable of anything.
answer: The trouble with you is that nobody can speak to you, that's all.

question: Giulia, don't you understand that the more involved you become with people, the more difficult it is to speak with them?
answer: You men are all so dreadful!

question: I hope so.
answer: How wonderful!

question: That's Patrizia's way of letting us know she's with us.
answer: I think you're very sweet, Corrado.

question: More so than the shark?
answer: There's no comparison.

question: Sandro... A month is too long a time. I have become used to being without you.
answer: You'll get over it soon. It's the usual anxiety.

question: A little more so this time.
answer: So, it will just take you a little longer to get over it.

question: But I think we should talk about it. Or are you fully convinced that we too won't understand each other?
answer: There will be plenty of time to talk about it later. We'll get married soon. That way we'll have more time...

question: In this case, getting married means nothing. Aren't we already the same as being married? And Corrado and Giulia -- aren't they already the same as being married?
answer: But why rattle your brains by arguing and talking... Believe me, Anna, words never help at all. They only serve to confuse. I love you, Anna. Isn't I that enough?

question: No. It's not enough... I told you before that I would like to get away for a while and be alone.
answer: But you just said that a month was too...

question: I mean, to stay away longer -- two months... a year... three years... Yes, I know, it sounds absurd. And I feel awful. The very idea of losing you makes me want to die... And yet... I... I just don't have the same feeling for you any more.
answer: And what about yesterday... at my house... didn't you have any feeling for me, even then?

question: From Panarea. Why?
answer: Ah, then it was you... I heard a boat leaving here at two o'clock today...

question: It must have been around four or five...
answer: In the afternoon?

question: Are you feeling better?
answer: I'm sorry about last night. Please forgive me.

question: You're very fond of Anna, aren't you?
answer: Yes, very much so.

question: Has she ever spoken to you about me?
answer: Occasionally, but always with affection.

question: And yet, she seemed to feel that our love for her -- mine, yours, even her father's, in a certain sense -- weren't enough for her, or didn't mean much to her.
answer: I know. I keep asking myself what I could have done to prevent all this from happening.

question: Whose boat is that?
answer: What boat?

question: Just a moment ago... didn't you hear the sound of a motor?
answer: At this time of the year there are so many boats...

question: And how come you're up so early?
answer: Early? Is four in the morning early for you?

question: Anything new develop?
answer: Unfortunately, no.

question: Very well. First of all, I'll have them search the waters around the island. I brought two frogmen with me... Meanwhile, we'll take a look up around here.
answer: Look, Marshal, with those deep crevasses, you'll need some rope and ladders...

question: Don't worry, we've got everything.
answer: Another thing; there's an old man who lives here on the island...

question: Yes... I'm going... I'm going now. It's already two hours... What are we going to do?
answer: It takes about twenty to twenty-two hours for the current to reach here from Lisca Bianca. If the girl disappeared yesterday afternoon, we'll have to wait at least until three or four o'clock. You see? It contains cigarettes. We'll have to confiscate it. These people are contemptible. They have no sense of dignity at all.

question: And you say that came from Lisca Bianca?
answer: It couldn't have come from anywhere else. At least, somewhere from that vicinity... But I really can't understand it. Contraband cigarettes on that island! It's the first time that ever happened.

question: Look... I'd like to get back to Lisca Bianca.
answer: But how could we...at a time like this when we just... well, let's at least first have a look around the other islands. Could be that something might turn up there.

question: But even here we were supposed to find who knows what... And all we bring back with us is a crate of cigarettes.
answer: As you wish.

question: I believe you, I believe you... But I'm also certain that you're hiding something from me. I can see it written all over your face... And you know that I have never liked your face. And if you want to know something, that gentleman over there... ...who's a very important person... doesn't like it either. So, just keep that in mind. I'll talk to you later.
answer: I presume by this method that you'll be able to uncover some new clue, either a handkerchief or an article of clothing... In other words, something which your men have not been able to find as yet.

question: Without any doubt, sir. If anything belonging to the girl who has run away is still here on this island...
answer: Allow me to inform you that my daughter is not a fugitive.

question: I'm sorry, sir. I didn't mean to put it that way. But, you must understand, sir, that I...
answer: I understand very well. Only I don't want any rash assumptions to be made.

question: Up until now those smugglers were operating only around the Palermo area. This will be a nice surprise for the Lieutenant in Milazzo... Call up headquarters. Bring them up to date and have them give you instructions on what to do with this crate.
answer: So... the boat we saw yesterday afternoon might have also been that of these smugglers. Could it be possible, then, that Anna...?

question: I wonder where they could have unloaded the stuff ... Maybe right here at Lisca.
answer: I was saying... it might even be possible that Anna had left with them.

question: But for what reason would she have wanted to go away?
answer: Listen, Marshal... As for there being reasons for going away, anyone of us might have three thousand of them. So you can assume that she had them. What I want to know, is it possible that the smugglers might have taken her aboard?

question: Pardon me for being so frank, but there are certain things that a father -- especially a father like you --cannot understand. So don't be stubborn. I'm coming with you. Patrizia, what are you going to do?
answer: What do you want us to do? I don't know myself... But we'll do something.

question: I'll go and get my valise.
answer: We've decided to go to Montaldo's place. In fact, Ettore should already be there.

question: At any rate, we'll continue investigating. I know that headquarters has sent out an alarm to all areas...
answer: Tell me, Lieutenant, do you happen to know this F.Z. who wrote this article here?

question: That's Francesco Zuria. He's the news correspondent.
answer: Where can we locate him? Don't you think that by offering a reward to anyone who can give us some information...

question: Zuria is in Messina. You might try him. Shall we phone him? Yes. With whom did you leave the crate of cigarettes?
answer: Pardon me, Sergeant, but when did you get back? And the young lady who was with you? Where are you going?... To Montaldo's?

question: Pardon me, Sergeant, but when did you get back? And the young lady who was with you? Where are you going?... To Montaldo's?
answer: Yes.

question: Then I'll go with you.
answer: Have you read it?... They're asking for anyone with information to get in touch with them.

question: Yes. I had also thought of going there to talk with them...
answer: Yes, you should go.

question: But then when will we see each other?
answer: I know it's difficult. But if you go on like this it will become even more difficult. Please, don't look so solemn... And don't wait for the train to come in. Please, please leave. I don't want to look out of the window and wave to you with a handkerchief. Go ahead, now say something! I want to know just what it is we have to say to each other. Sandro, I don't want you to come with me, I don't want to see you... How can I make it clear to you?...Why did you come?

question: I don't know why. I just couldn't help it.
answer: But sooner or later we've got to end this relationship. And it's better to do it right now.

question: I have no desire to sacrifice myself... It's idiotic to sacrifice oneself... Why?... For whom? If Anna were here I might understand your scruples. But she's not...
answer: Oh, Sandro...

question: I'm sorry. I didn't want to sound cynical. But isn't it better to look things squarely in the eye?
answer: For me they are exactly as they were when we met three days ago -- just three days ago... don't you realize? And you and Anna... No, I guess they aren't like that any more. My God, is it possible to forget in such a short time, for things to change so quickly?

question: It takes even less.
answer: But it's so sad. So terribly sad. I'm not used to it, I'm not ready for it... You know... I have never been so upset in my life. Sandro, why don't you help me?

question: I think the only way to help ourselves, Claudia, is for us to be together.
answer: No, I'm sure it won't. Move over there. Let's make believe nothing happened. And when we get to the next station, get off.

question: And what about you?
answer: Me... I... I... Please leave me alone.

question: I work there but I'm really a stranger.
answer: I tell you this acquaintance of mine knows you and she has often spoken to me about you.

question: And who is she? Does she work in Catania?
answer: Yes, she takes care of the garden.

question: Then it's impossible for her to know me. In the villa where I'm at, we have a male gardener.
answer: So? That's logical. You see, both being gardeners, they spoke about you to one another.

question: And what did they say about me?
answer: They told me that you were a very nice girl, that you always mind your business... In other words, things of that sort.

question: We have a radio like this, too.
answer: No, not like this one.

question: And why wouldn't we have one like this?
answer: Because this is a Chinese radio.

question: Certainly a radio this small is very practical. It's especially useful for... I don't know... for traveling.
answer: But for you, what comes first

question: Music, of course. To get a sweetheart, one has to look around, but to get a radio, all you have to do is buy one.
answer: Ah, no... For me, love comes first. I'm a man, and I know what's what

question: Did you have a good trip? It is such a magnificent day! I am very happy that Sicily is able to give you so warm a welcome. And you do deserve it. You're such a lovely blonde. Come, my dear. And where are you from?
answer: From Rome.

question: Oh, how nice! So, you're from Rome... And would you happen to know of some intelligent clergyman in Rome who might be willing to come here and stay with us? We have our own private little chapel... It is a masterpiece, with seventeenth-century frescoes... and the remains of all our dead ancestors, a wonderful collection... He would find it very convenient there, and could say his own masses. Then he would have to spend a little time with my husband, who never sees anyone, to keep him occupied.
answer: An intelligent clergyman, Princess? But I think the intelligent clergymen of today have so many other things to do.

question: Wait a moment. Can't you see I'm busy?
answer: I came down here to buy a foulard... Suddenly I realized that little by little, directly behind me, I was being followed by so many men, and more and more of them kept coming. But I have always gone around like this, everywhere in the world. Nothing like this has ever happened to me before.

question: How old are you?
answer: Nineteen. My name is Gloria Perkins. I'm married and a writer by profession. I write in a trance, almost always in contact with people who are dead. Tolstoi, for example, or Shakespeare. But the movies also interest me.

question: How do you find the men of Messina? Are you shocked by their warm display of friendliness?
answer: No, why should I be shocked? We're in Italy, not Finland.

question: And how were you received in Palermo?
answer: In Palermo I was with my husband. Now I'm going to Capri to write an article for the Tourist Office.

question: She did exactly the same thing in Palermo.
answer: Oh, yes, thank you...

question: Do you like her? She costs a hundred thousand lire.
answer: You're kidding!

question: No, I'm not. Why do you think she does all this? It's one of the many ways she can put herself on display. When you bait the trap, the mouse will snap. To tell you the truth, if it wasn't for the fact that one hundred thousand lire represents my whole month's salary, well... But you had something you wanted to ask me?
answer: I read one of your articles regarding the disappearance of a girl. I'm that girl's fianc.

question: Oh... I'm sorry I have to rush but I've got to write a story about this thing that just happened... Tell me exactly how it all turned out.
answer: Now listen, if I had any information, I wouldn't have come here to ask you. But I see that you, too, lack any information ...

question: As a matter of fact, I've already had several phone calls on that article. One said they had seen the missing girl in an automobile somewhere in Rome. Another one said they saw her on the pier talking with some strange sailors... Could be she secretly left the island by boat...
answer: Is that possible?

question: Who knows?... Another one has it that she entered a store in Troina. This information comes from the storekeeper himself who stated that such and such a girl had bought I don't know what in his store... at Troina.
answer: Is that far from here?

question: About fifty miles or so. If you want, I'll give you the name of the storekeeper.
answer: Yes... of course... But you should also print that in your paper... But right away, tomorrow morning... It's the local Palermo paper, isn't it?... I mean, it's widely read...

question: Yes, but why do you think our readers would be interested in such news now? Even if I sent it, the editors wouldn't print it.
answer: You really must do me this one favor.

question: Pardon me, but why must I do you a favor?
answer: Then let's call it a business proposition. Something to round out your salary.

question: Are you ready? I'm not. That's all we needed -- a cocktail party... The vitality some people have irritates me! How does it look?
answer: It's divine!

question: You say that just to flatter me.
answer: Do you consider that a compliment?

question: But why all nudes?
answer: Because there is no landscape as beautiful as a woman.

question: And where do you find the models?
answer: Oh, there are as many as one wants.

question: I thought the model was something obsolete nowadays. Didn't you, Claudia?
answer: It's strange how anxious women are to display themselves. It's almost a natural inclination.

question: But how could they pose like that? I couldn't.
answer: Why don't you try?

question: Don't you ever paint men?
answer: Answer me, why don't you try posing? I'll paint you a beautiful portrait.

question: But why me?... Ask Claudia, she's much more beautiful than me.
answer: But I want to paint you. You appeal to me more.

question: I appeal to you more?
answer: Giulia!

question: And tell Corrado, too, that I'm here... if he wants me. You can also tell him that my tiny little heart is beating like mad, and that at this moment, it's the only thing that interests me. Is that clear?
answer: It couldn't be any clearer.

question: Now what do I have to do to be left in peace?
answer: I think all you have to do, Giulia, is to close the door.

question: Well...probably at the last stop, which is Noto.
answer: After that, you didn't see her anymore?

question: What are you trying to insinuate, young lady? Why should I have seen her again? I don't do anything that's illegitimate.
answer: Oh, no... What are you saying? I'm not insinuating anything...

question: And furthermore, my dear young lady... because you really are a dear, you know ...if the story of that girl is merely a pretext, let us say, to get in touch with her, then I feel it is my duty to warn her. These things are very, very dangerous, especially in a neighborhood like this where people occupy themselves more with other people's affairs than their own.
answer: Then you should also be able to tell me where a young girl might stay in Noto; are there any hotels or rooming houses?

question: There's the Trinacria Hotel... or the Regina, near the municipal building. As for rooming houses, I don't know...
answer: Thank you.

question: Look at that bridge! Who knows why they even bothered to make it... Look at that It's late... We should be going. Let's get out of here, fast... This is not a town, it's a cemetery.
answer: Who knows why they all left...

question: Sandro ... maybe it's best that you go in alone.
answer: Are you joking?

question: Don't think that I want to save myself from any embarrassment, from the awkwardness of meeting Anna... It's not that; it's that you can say certain things easier if you're alone. Please, Sandro, do try to understand me... It would look like I was trying to influence you, to force you, to control you... and that makes me feel uncomfortable... Some cigarettes, please... Do you have any?... Nazionali with filters ...
answer: What is it, Claudia?

question: Oh, Sandro... I'm so ashamed of myself, so ashamed...I tried to hide myself...I feel so small... I hate myself ...
answer: Does it please you to say such things?

question: Oh no... It doesn't please me at all...
answer: Then why do you say them?

question: Because what I'm doing is so ugly ... Because if you told me right now No... Because then I'd force you to swear it, I'd force you to tell me an infinite amount of things... and that wouldn't be right, it couldn't be right... It would be absurd.
answer: Good. It's better if it were absurd. That would mean nothing much can be done about it.

question: But just think -- the very same things you had said to her who knows how many times... maybe even just before we left, while I was waiting outside your place...
answer: So, even if I did say them, I was sincere with her, as I am now with you. I have never seen a woman like you, who needs to see everything so clearly. At one time, all these houses were convents. Look! What a fantastic scene! What movement, what disorder! They were very much concerned with scenographic effects... an extraordinary sense of liberty... Really, I've got to stop this business with Ettore... I would like to go back and start working on my own projects again. You know, I had many ideas...

question: And why did you drop them?
answer: Once they gave me a job to draw up an estimate for the construction of a school. It took me only a day and a half to finish it, and I got paid six million lire. Ever since then I've been doing estimates for other people's designs. Why are you looking at me like that?

question: I'm sure you'd be able to design some very lovely things.
answer: I don't know about that. And then, who's interested in beautiful things nowadays? Claudia, let's get married?

question: What! Get married?
answer: Yes. We'll get married. You and I. What do you say?

question: What do I say? What can I say? No. At least, not yet. I don't know... I can't even think of it... at a time like this... Oh, but why did you have to ask me?
answer: You look at me as though I had said something foolish...

question: And are you sure you want to marry me? Are you really sure...that you want to marry... me?
answer: That's why I asked you...

question: So... Oh, how I wish that everything were so much simpler... that people could just come together by the color of their hair or the size of their shoes. What size shoe do you wear? Size 9. That's a very lovely size. But I'm sorry, I wear size 8.
answer: Are you ready?

question: But why am I so infatuated with you?
answer: Hurry up now, or it'll begin to get hot outside...

question: Yes, yes, yes, yes... Right away...
answer: Okay. I understand. See you later.

question: And you leave me here all alone... in this hotel room...
answer: As soon as you're ready, you can come down and catch up with me. I'll be waiting for you right outside on the square.

question: Very well. But you must first tell me that when you go out without me it's like going out without one of your legs. Go ahead, have a look around the town all by yourself, but you'll have to hobble along on only one leg. And you must also tell me that you are filled with a great desire to embrace my shadow on the walls... Then you must tell me... You must tell me that you love me.
answer: But you know it already. Why must I tell you?

question: So, you wonder why?
answer: Then I'll see you later.

question: Okay. In a few minutes.
answer: It's closed. Isn't there any custodian or caretaker inside? But it says it's open from 9:30 to 10:30., and it's ten o'clock now... That's a fine way to greet tourists. Are you the custodian?

question: I was just coming out to meet you. How come you're back so soon? Sandro ...What's the matter?
answer: Nothing.

question: No, Sandro... Please...
answer: Why?

question: No reason why... What's the matter with you? Sandro, wait a moment, just one moment... You seem like an entirely different person ...
answer: And aren't you pleased?... That way you'll have a new kind of adventure.

question: What are you saying?
answer: I was only joking, really... Can't I make a joke? And now you've got to tell me why you don't want to.

question: Oh, Sandro... I want everything you do. But...
answer: But what?

question: Did the hotel manager speak to you about that place nearby?
answer: Yes, she started to but I didn't feel like staying to listen to what she had to say. If we had to listen to everybody...

question: No, Sandro... We should go. Besides, we haven't been in touch with anybody. Not even with Anna's father. We should have at least sent a wire or telephoned... let's be fair, he must be feeling awfully lonely.
answer: I don't doubt it. But at a time like this we're the least suitable persons to be with him. And as far as telephoning him... Who knows where he is?

question: Quieter? Oh, yes, of course. You look so wonderfully tanned. And here's Sandro. Why don't you two go upstairs and change?
answer: Yes, we will.

question: Did you manage to find good rooms?
answer: They didn't seem too good.

question: You should have told Ettore. He always manages to get what he wants.
answer: Ettore must be fed up with me by now.

question: Yes, even I had a mother. She was part Austrian, but she was still my mother. My childhood was like a tennis match; they bounced me back and forth, here and there...
answer: My childhood, instead, was a very sensible one.

question: What do you mean by sensible?
answer: It means being without money.

question: You see? Just like a robot. Come in.
answer: Sandro, listen... Try not to get yourself too involved tomorrow.

question: Aren't you going to change?
answer: You said you wanted to quit working for Ettore.

question: Sure, that's what I said... Wow, it's ice cold...
answer: Sandro, I'm not coming down.

question: Why?
answer: I'm too sleepy.

question: Sleep is something one must learn to overcome. I learned how to do it when I was a child. I never slept. And I had friends who even slept less than I did. The one who went to bed first, paid a penalty. And we really didn't do anything. After seeing a movie, we'd go to a cafe and discuss things for a while... then we'd sit down on a bench somewhere... listen to some drunkard... watch them putting up posters or manifestoes...or look at the sheep passing by... or go for a stroll around the market place... Or else we'd go and wake up some girl in the neighborhood by standing in front of her window and calling out her name... You're that sleepy, eh? What time do expect to get up tomorrow?
answer: Late, very late.

question: Did you know that when I was a boy I wanted to be a diplomat? Can you imagine that! Me, a diplomat? It's strange but I never thought I'd be rich. I saw myself living in a rooming house, full of geniuses... Instead, I have two apartments, one in Rome and one in Milan. As far as genius goes, it's a habit I've never formed. What do you think of that?
answer: I look at things differently... But maybe it's best we talk about it some other time. Do you mind turning off that light over there?

question: Good night, my love.
answer: Good night. Tell me that you love me.

question: I love you.
answer: Tell me once more.

question: I don't love you.
answer: I deserve it.

question: Ettore...
answer: What is it?

question: Nothing, nothing at all. I was just looking for Sandro.
answer: And you expect to find him in here? Go and ask Claudia.
